p: In order to reveal the expression changes of the most important virulence-associated genes, we have investigated 23 target genes. These genes are known to be clearly associated with virulence and were used in one of our previous studies [ 15]. The varying degrees of influence of this 23 investigated virulence-associated genes suggest that PEO could have an effect on different targets and regulatory routes. The drastic suppression (0,08x) of cadF and cbf2 (PEB4A) [ 6], 2 characterized adhesive proteins of C. jejuni, correlates with recent findings where antiadhesive effects of different extracts of C. jejuni on different surfaces were investigated [ 14, 49]. On the other hand, the increased expression of PEB1 [ 5] and PEB3 [ 41] ( Table 2.), 2 proteins also thought to be involved in adhesion, suggests that PEO might also increase the expression of certain virulence-associated genes.
